Award.AwardTitle: A Survey of Nearby Stars for Extrasolar Planets: Towards a Galactic Census of Terrestrial Planets
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Steven Vogt will continue a long-term effort to discover and characterize planets around nearby stars. He and his group will obtain high-resolution spectra at the W. M. Keck Observatory, the Anglo-Australian Telescope, and the Magellan Telescopes of the Carnegie Observatories to measure precise radial velocities. The study will reveal the presence of unseen planets around stars by detecting periodic variations in the radial velocity of the host star due to gravitational acceleration induced by the unseen planet. The goal of the project is to identify new planets in multi-planet systems and also around stars not yet known to harbor planets. In cases where a planet also transits its host star, infrared and optical light curves of the primary and secondary transits will yield further information about mass, density, structure, temperature, and atmospheric conditions on the planet. The long-term goal of the research is to push the planet detection threshold into the terrestrial-mass regime, and determine the occurrence frequency of habitable terrestrial planets.

This effort aims to provide fundamental observational data about the origins and evolution of planetary systems, and determine whether our own solar system (with low-mass rocky planets in the inner zone, and massive Jovian gas giants in the outer zone) is common or rare in the universe. Dr. Vogt's group will continue outreach efforts with K-12 students and the general population; they will also work with amateur and professional astronomers, who can perform orbit determination using a web-based tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 20 years, under NSF support, we have developed the technology and techniques to detect planets around other stars by detecting the velocity wobble imparted on planet-hosting stars by their planets. Most of this work was carried out at Keck Observatory in Hawaii, with its HIRES spectrometer providing the requisite high resolution spectra from which we extract precision velocities of planet-hosting stars to discern their reflex wobble and thereby characterize the planets in orbit around them.

Our planet survey program has accounted for a large fraction of the currently known extrasolar planets detected from ground-based techniques, making it one of the most productive and successful of any such ground-based planet search program. Our work has compiled a long list of firsts in the Exoplanet field: first transiting planet, first sub-Neptune planets, first Super-Earth planets, first multple-planet systems, first potentially-habitable rocky planets, etc. Our Iodine-based precision velocity reference technology has been widely copied and used productively by others in the field. We also have developed and maintain a publicly-available software system (SYSTEMIC) for extracting orbital parameters from complex radial velocity data sets.

The results from our work have fueled an entirely new field of planetary research: Extrasolar Planets. Each new result from our work causes tremendous excitement in the scientific community as theorists strive to understand the unexpected diversity of the extrasolar planets, and to fit our knowledge of these new systems into our understanding of our own solar system and planetary systems in general.

In recent years, our team's efforts have been highly focussed on finding and characterizing potentially habitable rocky Earth-sized planets orbiting the very nearest stars. To this end, we have created The Automated Planet Finder (APF), a 2.4-m telescope at Lick Observatory's Mt. Hamilton site 20 miles east of San Jose, CA. APF is almost exclusively devoted to obtaining very high precision radial velocities of nearby stars, night after night, in support of the search for other nearby Earth-sized planets.

Our radial velocity program is one of only a handful of programs around the world that could be relied upon to make exoplanet detections around the nearby stars over the coming decade. These nearby stars are systems that are bright enough and close enough to allow detailed follow up for atmospheric spectroscopy and IR photometry, identifying potentially habitable Earth-sized planets, and perhaps allowing eventual detection of biomarker gasses in their atmospheres. Over the coming centuries, these will be the stars that will become targets of the first unmanned interstellar probes.
